content.question:
A cylindrical container has a thermally conductive barrier that separates the container into two sections, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, as shown. The container is thermally isolated from its surroundings. Each section contains an ideal gas. Initially at time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, the gas in Section <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> has <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> gas atoms with average kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> and the gas in Section <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> has <math alttext="2 N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>N</mi></math> gas atoms with average kinetic energy <math alttext="K over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. A long time later at time <math alttext="t sub equilibrium" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>eq</mtext></msub></math>, the gases are in thermal equilibrium with each other. Which of the following correctly compares the temperatures <math alttext="T sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> of the gases in sections <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, respectively, at the times <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="t sub equilibrium" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>eq</mtext></msub></math>?
At time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>At time <math alttext="t sub equilibrium" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>eq</mtext></msub></math>A<math alttext="T sub X is less than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math><math alttext="T sub X is less than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>B<math alttext="T sub X is less than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math><math alttext="T sub X equals T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>C<math alttext="T sub X is greater than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math><math alttext="T sub X is less than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>D<math alttext="T sub X is greater than T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math><math alttext="T sub X equals T sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
